The **economy of Uganda** has great potential and appears poised for rapid
growth and development. Uganda is endowed with significant natural resources,
including ample fertile land, regular rainfall, and mineral deposits.

Chronic political instability and erratic economic management since the
implementation of self-rule has produced a record of persistent economic
decline that has left Uganda among of the world's poorest and least-developed
countries. The informal economy, which is predominantly female, is broadly
defined as a group of vulnerable individuals without protections in regards to
their work. Women face a plethora of barriers specific to gender when
attempting to access the formal economy of Uganda, and research revealed
prejudice against lending to women in the informal sector. The national energy
needs have historically exceeded the domestic energy generation, though large
petroleum reserves have been found in the country's west.

After the turmoil of the Amin period, the country began a program of economic
recovery in 1981 that received considerable foreign assistance. From mid-1984
onward, overly expansionist fiscal and monetary policies and the renewed
outbreak of civil strife led to a setback in economic performance.

The economy has grown since the 1990s; real gross domestic product (GDP) grew
at an average of 6.7% annually during the period 1990–2015, whereas real GDP
per capita grew at 3.3% per annum during the same period. During this period,
the Ugandan economy experienced economic transformation: the share of
agriculture value added in GDP declined from 56% in 1990 to 24% in 2015; the
share of industry grew from 11% to 20% (with manufacturing increasing at a
slower pace, from 6% to 9% of GDP); and the share of services went from 32% to
55%.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Uganda possesses significant potential for rapid growth and development, supported by abundant natural resources such as fertile land, consistent rainfall, and mineral deposits.

• Since the establishment of self-rule, Uganda has experienced chronic political instability and erratic economic management, resulting in persistent economic decline and positioning the country among the world’s poorest and least-developed nations.

• The informal economy in Uganda is predominantly female and consists of vulnerable individuals lacking work protections; women face numerous gender-specific barriers to accessing the formal economy, including documented prejudice against lending to women in the informal sector.
• Uganda’s national energy demand has historically surpassed its domestic energy generation capacity, despite the discovery of substantial petroleum reserves in the western region of the country.
• Following the turmoil during the Amin regime, Uganda initiated an economic recovery program in 1981, which was supported by considerable foreign assistance.
• From mid-1984 onwards, Uganda’s economic progress was hindered by overly expansionist fiscal and monetary policies and the resurgence of civil conflict, leading to setbacks in economic performance.

• Between 1990 and 2015, Uganda’s economy experienced growth with real gross domestic product (GDP) increasing at an average annual rate of 6.7%, while real GDP per capita grew at 3.3% per year during the same period.

• The period from 1990 to 2015 saw significant economic transformation in Uganda: the contribution of agriculture to GDP declined from 56% to 24%; the industrial sector’s share increased from 11% to 20%, with manufacturing growing more slowly from 6% to 9% of GDP; and the services sector expanded substantially from 32% to 55% of GDP.

Ugandan export destinations in 2006

Since assuming power in early 1986, Museveni's government has taken important
steps toward economic rehabilitation. The country's infrastructure, notably
its transport and communications systems which were destroyed by war and
neglect, is being rebuilt. Recognizing the need for increased external
support, Uganda negotiated a policy framework paper with the IMF and the World
Bank in 1987. Uganda subsequently began implementing economic policies
designed to restore price stability and sustainable balance of payments,
improve capacity utilization, rehabilitate infrastructure, restore producer
incentives through proper price policies, and improve resource mobilization
and allocation in the public sector. These so-called Structural Adjustment
Programs greatly improved the shape of the Ugandan economy, but did not lead
to economic growth in the first decade after their implementation. Since 1995,
Uganda has experienced rapid economic growth, but it is not clear to what
extent this positive development can be attributed to Structural Adjustment.
Uganda has been a member of the World Trade Organization, since January 1st
1995 and a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, since October
25th 1962.
openai_summarised_points: • Since assuming power in early 1986, President Yoweri Museveni's government has undertaken significant measures aimed at economic rehabilitation in Uganda.
• The country's infrastructure, particularly its transport and communications systems, which had been severely damaged by war and neglect, is undergoing reconstruction.
• In 1987, Uganda negotiated a policy framework paper with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank to secure increased external support for its economic recovery.
• Following this agreement, Uganda implemented economic policies focused on restoring price stability and achieving a sustainable balance of payments.

• These policies also aimed to improve capacity utilization, rehabilitate infrastructure, restore producer incentives through appropriate price policies, and enhance resource mobilization and allocation within the public sector.

• The economic reforms, known as Structural Adjustment Programs (SAPs), significantly improved the overall condition of Uganda’s economy but did not result in economic growth during the first decade after their implementation.
• Since 1995, Uganda has experienced rapid economic growth; however, the extent to which this growth can be directly attributed to the Structural Adjustment Programs remains uncertain.
• Uganda has been a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) since January 1, 1995.
• Prior to joining the WTO, Uganda was a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) since October 25, 1962.

• The responsibility for issuing Uganda's currency was undertaken by the Bank of Uganda, the country's central bank.

Agricultural products supply a significant portion of Uganda's foreign
exchange earnings, with coffee alone, of which Uganda is Africa's second
largest producer after Ethiopia, accounting for about 17% of the country's
exports in 2017 and earning the country US$545 million. Exports of apparel,
hides, skins, vanilla, vegetables, fruits, cut flowers, and fish are growing,
while cotton, tea, and tobacco continue to be mainstays.

Uganda produced in 2018:

* 3.9 million tons of sugarcane
* 3.8 million tons of plantain (4th largest producer in the world, losing only to Congo, Ghana and Cameroon)
* 2.9 million tons of maize
* 2.6 million tons of cassava
* 1.5 million tons of sweet potato (7th largest producer in the world)
* 1.0 million tons of bean
* 1.0 million tons of vegetable
* 532 thousand tons of banana
* 360 thousand tons of onion
* 298 thousand tons of sorghum
* 260 thousand tons of rice
* 245 thousand tons of sunflower seed
* 242 thousand tons of peanut
* 211 thousand tons of coffee (10th largest producer in the world)
* 209 thousand tons of millet

In addition, there are smaller productions of other agricultural products,
like cotton (87 thousand tons), tea (62 thousand tons), tobacco (35 thousand
tons) and cocoa (27 thousand tons).
openai_summarised_points: • Agricultural products constitute a significant portion of Uganda's foreign exchange earnings, with coffee being a major contributor; Uganda is Africa's second largest coffee producer after Ethiopia, and coffee accounted for approximately 17% of Uganda's exports in 2017, generating US$545 million in revenue.

• Besides coffee, Uganda's export portfolio includes growing sectors such as apparel, hides, skins, vanilla, vegetables, fruits, cut flowers, and fish, while traditional exports like cotton, tea, and tobacco remain important staples of the economy.
• In 2018, Uganda produced 3.9 million tons of sugarcane, making it one of the country's leading agricultural outputs by volume.
• Uganda produced 3.8 million tons of plantain in 2018, ranking as the 4th largest producer globally, behind Congo, Ghana, and Cameroon.
• Maize production in Uganda reached 2.9 million tons in 2018, reflecting its significance as a staple crop.
• Cassava production was recorded at 2.6 million tons in 2018, underscoring its role in Uganda's agriculture.
• Sweet potato production totaled 1.5 million tons in 2018, positioning Uganda as the 7th largest producer worldwide.
• Uganda produced 1.0 million tons of beans in 2018, highlighting its importance in the agricultural sector.
• Vegetable production also reached 1.0 million tons in 2018, indicating a substantial output in this category.
• Banana production was 532 thousand tons in 2018, contributing to Uganda's diverse agricultural portfolio.
• Onion production amounted to 360 thousand tons in 2018, reflecting its role in local agriculture.
• Sorghum production was 298 thousand tons in 2018, supporting both food security and economic activities.
• Rice production reached 260 thousand tons in 2018, indicating its growing importance in Uganda's crop production.
• Sunflower seed production totaled 245 thousand tons in 2018, contributing to the oilseed sector.
• Peanut production was 242 thousand tons in 2018, supporting both domestic consumption and export potential.
• Coffee production was 211 thousand tons in 2018, ranking Uganda as the 10th largest coffee producer globally.
• Millet production amounted to 209 thousand tons in 2018, adding to the diversity of cereal crops in Uganda.

• Smaller scale production in 2018 included cotton at 87 thousand tons, tea at 62 thousand tons, tobacco at 35 thousand tons, and cocoa at 27 thousand tons, maintaining their roles as important but less voluminous agricultural commodities.

As of 2017, Uganda had about 130,000 kilometres (80,778 mi) of roads, with
approximately 5,300 kilometres (3,293 mi) (4 percent) paved. Most paved roads
radiate from Kampala, the country's capital and largest city.

As of 2017, Uganda's metre gauge railway network measures about 1,250
kilometres (777 mi) in length. Of this, about 56% (700 kilometres (435 mi)),
is operational. A railroad originating at Mombasa on the Indian Ocean connects
with Tororo, where it branches westward to Jinja, Kampala, and Kasese and
northward to Mbale, Soroti, Lira, Gulu, and Pakwach. The only railway line
still operating, however, is the one to Kampala.

Uganda's important link to the port of Mombasa is now mainly by road, which
serves its transport needs and also those of neighboring Rwanda, Burundi,
parts of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and South Sudan.

An international airport is at Entebbe on the northern shores of Lake
Victoria, about 41 kilometres (25 mi) south of Kampala. In January 2018, the
government of Uganda began the construction of Kabalega International Airport,
in the Western Region of Uganda. This will be Uganda's second international
airport, which is planned to facilitate the construction of an oil refinery
and boost tourism.

The transport union Amalgamated Transport and General Workers Union (ATWGU) is
one of the more powerful trade unions in the country with about 100,000
members, many of whom are informal workers.
openai_summarised_points: • As of 2017, Uganda possessed approximately 130,000 kilometres (80,778 miles) of roads, with about 5,300 kilometres (3,293 miles), representing 4 percent, being paved; the majority of these paved roads radiate from Kampala, the capital and largest city of Uganda.
• Uganda's metre gauge railway network, as of 2017, extends roughly 1,250 kilometres (777 miles), of which approximately 56 percent (700 kilometres or 435 miles) is operational.

• The railway system originates at Mombasa on the Indian Ocean and connects to Tororo, where it branches westward to Jinja, Kampala, and Kasese, and northward to Mbale, Soroti, Lira, Gulu, and Pakwach; however, the only railway line currently operational is the one leading to Kampala.

• Uganda’s critical transport link to the port of Mombasa is primarily maintained by road transport, which also serves the logistical needs of neighboring countries including Rwanda, Burundi, parts of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and South Sudan.
• The country’s international airport is located at Entebbe on the northern shores of Lake Victoria, approximately 41 kilometres (25 miles) south of Kampala.

• In January 2018, the Ugandan government commenced construction of Kabalega International Airport in the Western Region, which is planned to be Uganda’s second international airport, intended to support the development of an oil refinery and to enhance tourism.

• The Amalgamated Transport and General Workers Union (ATWGU) is a significant trade union within Uganda’s transport sector, boasting about 100,000 members, many of whom are informal workers, and is recognized as one of the more powerful unions in the country.

The Uganda Communications Commission regulates communications, primarily
"delivered through an enabled private sector." The companies it regulates
include television networks, radio stations, mobile network operators, and
fixed-line telephone companies.
openai_summarised_points: • The Uganda Communications Commission (UCC) serves as the regulatory authority overseeing the communications sector in Uganda.
• The UCC primarily regulates communications services that are delivered through an enabled private sector framework.
• The scope of the UCC's regulatory oversight includes television networks operating within Uganda.
• Radio stations broadcasting in Uganda fall under the regulatory jurisdiction of the Uganda Communications Commission.
• Mobile network operators providing cellular and mobile communication services in Uganda are regulated by the UCC.
• Fixed-line telephone companies offering traditional wired telephony services in Uganda are also subject to UCC regulation.

Uganda's predominant mineral occurrences are gold, tungsten, tin, beryl, and
tantalite in the south; tungsten, clay, and granite between latitude zero and
two degrees north; and gold, mica, copper, limestone, and iron in the north.

In late 2012, the government of Uganda was taken to court over value added tax
that it placed on goods and services purchased by Tullow Oil, a foreign oil
company operating in the country at the time. The court case was heard at an
international court based in the United States. The Ugandan government
insisted that Tullow could not claim taxes on supplies as recoverable costs
before oil production starts. Sources from within the government reveal that
the main concern at present is the manner in which millions of dollars have
been lost in the past decade, money that could allegedly have stayed in Uganda
for investment in the public sector; a Global Financial Integrity report
recently revealed that illicit money flows from Uganda between 2001 and 2012
totalled $680 million. Tullow Oil was represented in the court case by Kampala
Associated Advocates, whose founder is Elly Kurahanga, the President of Tullow
Uganda. A partner at Kampala Associated Advocates, Peter Kabatsi, was also
Uganda's solicitor general between 1990 and 2002, and he has denied claims
that he negotiated contracts with foreign oil firms during his time in this
role.

In June 2015, the Ugandan government and Tullow Oil settled a longstanding
dispute regarding the amount of certain capital gains taxes that the company
owed to the government. The government claimed that the company owed US$435
million. The claim, however, was settled for US$250 million.

In April 2018, the government signed agreements with Albertine Graben Refinery
Consortium, an International consortium led by General Electric of the United
States, to build a 60,000 barrels-per-day Uganda Oil Refinery in Western
Uganda. The cost of the development is budgeted at about US$4 billion.
openai_summarised_points: • Uganda's primary mineral resources are distributed regionally: gold, tungsten, tin, beryl, and tantalite are predominantly found in the southern part of the country; tungsten, clay, and granite occur between latitude zero and two degrees north; and gold, mica, copper, limestone, and iron are located in the northern region.

• In late 2012, the Ugandan government was involved in an international legal dispute concerning value added tax (VAT) imposed on goods and services purchased by Tullow Oil, a foreign oil company operating in Uganda at that time; the case was heard at an international court based in the United States.
• The Ugandan government maintained that Tullow Oil could not claim taxes on supplies as recoverable costs prior to the commencement of oil production.
• Internal government sources expressed concern about the loss of millions of dollars over the previous decade, funds that could have been retained within Uganda for public sector investment.
• A report by Global Financial Integrity revealed that illicit financial outflows from Uganda between 2001 and 2012 amounted to $680 million.
• Tullow Oil was legally represented in the court case by Kampala Associated Advocates, a law firm founded by Elly Kurahanga, who also serves as the President of Tullow Uganda.

• Peter Kabatsi, a partner at Kampala Associated Advocates and Uganda’s former solicitor general from 1990 to 2002, denied allegations that he negotiated contracts with foreign oil companies during his tenure as solicitor general.

• In June 2015, the Ugandan government and Tullow Oil reached a settlement to resolve a longstanding dispute over capital gains taxes; the government initially claimed that Tullow owed US$435 million, but the matter was settled for US$250 million.

• In April 2018, the Ugandan government signed agreements with the Albertine Graben Refinery Consortium, an international consortium led by General Electric of the United States, to construct a 60,000 barrels-per-day oil refinery in Western Uganda.
• The planned Uganda Oil Refinery project is budgeted to cost approximately US$4 billion.

text:
The agriculture sector of the Ugandan economy, which composes roughly 40% of
the country's GDP, is largely fulfilled by women laborers, especially in
managing products, marketing, and the crop sub-sector.****76% of women work in
the agriculture sector and roughly 66% of men do, and women provide for 80% of
food crops and 60% of traditional exports such as coffee or tea. In the
formal, non-agricultural economy, men constitute 61% of the workforce, whereas
women predominate the informal economy, and this can be attributed to the lack
of equity between men and women in the country. The Uganda Bureau of
Statistics reported, when looking at the urban workforce in 2015, 88.6% of
women were employed informally, and 84.2% of men were. Women are unable to
enter into certain sectors, especially in the formal economy, due to the
inability to provide substantial initial funding, and remain in the trade and
service sectors of the economy. Comparatively, men dominate the more
profitable sectors, such as manufacturing. Women traders make up 70% of those
in markets and 40% in shops in addition to dominating other sectors such as
the service industry, crafts, and tailoring.

Women are often undervalued in data compilation, particularly when considering
their role in their domestic home lives. For example, women commonly match the
contribution of their husbands to their familial income, if not provide more,
when taking into consideration the value of their labor and the profits made
from selling excess food. Urban women on average earn between 50% and 70% of a
household's income. Women are also discredited in data collection due to
biases of data collectors resulting in inaccurate reports, as well as income
being measured per house, rather than separating by gender. The barriers women
face in furthering their entrepreneurial careers are different from those
faced by men; this is inherent in the biased culture and institutions plaguing
Uganda despite the passing of somewhat progressive policies, especially with
the 1985 transition of government to the National Resistance Movement
party.****
openai_summarised_points: • The agriculture sector constitutes approximately 40% of Uganda's GDP and is predominantly supported by women laborers, who play key roles in product management, marketing, and the crop sub-sector.
• Women represent 76% of the workforce in the agriculture sector, compared to roughly 66% of men, highlighting their significant involvement in this area.
• Women contribute to 80% of food crop production and 60% of traditional exports, including coffee and tea, underscoring their critical role in Uganda’s agricultural exports.
• In the formal, non-agricultural economy, men make up 61% of the workforce, whereas women predominantly occupy the informal economy, reflecting gender disparities in economic participation.

• According to the Uganda Bureau of Statistics in 2015, 88.6% of urban women were employed informally, compared to 84.2% of urban men, indicating a higher prevalence of informal employment among women.
• Women face barriers to entering certain formal economic sectors due to their inability to provide substantial initial funding, resulting in their concentration in trade and service sectors.
• Men dominate more profitable sectors such as manufacturing, while women traders constitute 70% of market vendors and 40% of shopkeepers, also dominating service industries, crafts, and tailoring.

• Women’s economic contributions are often undervalued in data collection, especially regarding their domestic roles, where they frequently match or exceed their husbands’ contributions to household income through labor and sales of surplus food.
• Urban women contribute between 50% and 70% of household income on average, demonstrating their substantial economic role within families.

• Data collection biases, including gender-insensitive methodologies and income measurement at the household rather than individual level, lead to the underreporting and discrediting of women’s economic contributions.
• Women face distinct barriers to entrepreneurial advancement compared to men, rooted in Uganda’s biased cultural and institutional frameworks despite progressive policy changes.

• The 1985 political transition to the National Resistance Movement party marked a period of somewhat progressive policies, yet gender biases in economic participation and institutional support persist.
